section.title: Sami spell checking in Linux
section.p: If you install the North and Lule Sami hunspell dictionaries, you can get system wide spelling support for these two languages. This document tells you how to achieve this.

section.title: Installing and setting up spell checking

ul.li: Unpack the tarball: tar zxvf hunspell-se.tar.gz
Go in to the hunspell-se-<version> directory: cd hunspell-se-<version>
Install the dictionaries: sudo make install

To check if the North Sami dictionary is installed, type hunspell -D. In the list that appears, you should see these items:
/usr/share/myspell/dicts/se_FI
/usr/share/myspell/dicts/se_NO
/usr/share/myspell/dicts/se_SE
Unpack the tarball: tar zxvf hunspell-smj.tar.gz
Go in to the hunspell-smj-<version> directory: cd hunspell-smj-<version>
Install the dictionaries: sudo make install

To check if the Lule Sami dictionary is installed, type hunspell -D. In the list that appears, you should see these items:
/usr/share/myspell/dicts/smj_NO
/usr/share/myspell/dicts/smj_SE

section.title: Setting up Sami spell checking in KDE

ul.li:
The «Northern Sami» entry will give Northern Sami spell checking.
Choosing the empty entry will give Lule Sami spell checking. (The Lule Sami entry is empty because KDE doesn't know anything about Lule Sami.)

section.p:
Every KDE application will now spell check in the chosen language. Try e.g. the mail application, KMail,
or the chat application Kopete.
Even the text fields in Konqueror (the web browser) will do spell checking. Here is a screenshot from gulesider.no, sending an SMS through the browser.
Pure magic!

section.title: Setting up Northern Sami spell checking in Gnome

ul.li: From the System menu, choose Administration->Language Support

In the window that appears, choose Northern Sami in the startup and login pulldown menu.
After this you will probably be asked to install some packages. Say yes to everything.

section.p: Every Gnome application now has spelling support for Northern Sami. Try e.g. the Outlook replacement Evolution, the chat application Pidgin or the text editor Gedit. Pure magic! Here are some examples from the chat program Pidgin.
